What were [the children]1036-the children doing?—that ought to have been [her]323-marjorie preoccupation . [She]323-marjorie did n't know ; [she]323-marjorie did n't care ! [Trafford]508-trafford came and stood beside [her]323-marjorie , pointed out this and that upon [the landing stage]4159-the landing stage , no longer heavily sullen , but alert , interested , almost gay .... [Neither of [them]4161-they]4160-neither of them could find any way to the great discussion [they]4161-they had set out upon , in this voyage to [St. John]206-st. john 's 's . But there was plenty of time before [them]4161-they . Plenty of time ! [They]4161-they were both the prey of that uneasy distraction which seems the inevitable quality of [a passenger steamship]4162-a passenger steamship . [They]4161-they surveyed and criticized [[their]4161-they fellow travellers]4163-their fellow travellers , and prowled up and down through the long swaying days and the cold dark nights . [They]4161-they slept uneasily amidst fog - horn hootings and the startling sounds of waves swirling against [the ports]4164-the ports . [Marjorie]323-marjorie had never had a long sea voyage before ; for the first time in [her]323-marjorie life [she]323-marjorie saw all [the world]589-the world , through a succession of days , as a circle of endless blue waters , with the stars and planets and sun and moon rising sharply from [its]4166-its rim . Until one has had a voyage [no one]4871-no one really understands that [old Earth]207-old earth is [a watery globe]4168-a watery globe .... [They]4161-they ran into thirty hours of storm , which subsided , and then came a slow time among icebergs , and a hooting , dreary passage through fog . [The first three icebergs]4169-the first three icebergs were marvels , the rest bores ; [a passing collier]4170-a passing collier out of [her]4170-a passing collier course and pitching heavily , [a lonely black and dirty ship]4171-a lonely black and dirty ship with a manner almost derelict , filled [their]4161-they thoughts for half a day . [Their]4161-they minds were in a state of tedious inactivity , eager for such small interests and only capable of such small interests . There was no hurry to talk , [they]4161-they agreed , no hurry at all , until [they]4161-they were settled away ahead there among the snows . " There [we]4161-they shall have plenty of time for everything .... "[508-trafford] Came the landfall and then [St. John 's]206-st. john 's , and [they]4161-they found [themselves]4161-they side by side watching [the town]828-the town draw near . The thought of landing and transference to [another ship]4173-another ship refreshed [them]4161-they both .... [They]4161-they were going , [Trafford]508-trafford said , in search of [God]249-god , but it was far more like [two children]4174-two children starting out upon a holiday . There was trouble and procrastination about [the half - breed guides that [Trafford]508-trafford had arranged]4175-the half - breed guides that trafford had arranged should meet [them]4161-they at [St. John]206-st. john 's 's , and it was three weeks from [their]4161-they reaching [Newfoundland]209-newfoundland before [they]4161-they got [themselves]4161-they and [[their]4161-they guides]4176-their guides and equipment and general stores aboard [the boat]1526-the boat for [Port Dupré]210-port dupré . Thence [he]508-trafford had planned [they]4161-they should go in [the Gibson schooner]4178-the gibson schooner to [Manivikovik]211-manivikovik , [the Marconi station]4179-the marconi station at [the mouth of [the Green River]212-the green river]4180-the mouth of the green river , and thence past [the new pulp - mills]4181-the new pulp - mills [up river]4182-up river to [the wilderness]4183-the wilderness . There were delays and a few trivial , troublesome complications in carrying out this scheme , but at last a day came when [Trafford]508-trafford could wave good - bye to [the seven people and eleven dogs which constituted [the population of [Peter Hammond]536-hammond 's]4185-the population of peter hammond 's , [that last rude outpost of civilization twenty miles above [the pulp - mill]4187-the pulp - mill]4186-that last rude outpost of civilization twenty miles above the pulp - mill , and turn [his]508-trafford face in good earnest towards [the wilderness]4183-the wilderness]4184-the seven people and eleven dogs which constituted the population of peter hammond 's , that last rude outpost of civilization twenty miles above the pulp - mill , and turn his face in good earnest towards the wilderness . Neither [he]508-trafford nor [Marjorie]323-marjorie looked back at [the headland]4189-the headland for a last glimpse of [the little settlement [they]4191-they were leaving]4190-the little settlement they were leaving . [Each]3862-each stared ahead over [the broad , smooth sweep of water]4193-the broad , smooth sweep of water , broken by [one transverse bar of foaming shallows]4194-one transverse bar of foaming shallows , and scanned [the low , tree - clad hills beyond that drew together at last in [the distant gorge out of which the river came]4196-the distant gorge out of which the river came]4195-the low , tree - clad hills beyond that drew together at last in the distant gorge out of which the river came . The morning was warm and full of the promise of a hot noon , so that the veils [they]4191-they wore against the assaults of sand - flies and mosquitoes were already a little inconvenient . It seemed incredible in this morning glow that the wooded slopes along [the shore of [the lake]5329-the lake]4197-the shore of the lake were the border of [a land in which nearly half [the inhabitants]4200-the inhabitants die of starvation]4199-a land in which nearly half the inhabitants die of starvation . The deep - laden canoes swept almost noiselessly through the water with a rhythmic alternation of rush and pause as the dripping paddles drove and returned . Altogether there were [four long canoes]4201-four long canoes and five Indian breeds in [[their]4191-they party]4202-their party , and when [they]4191-they came to pass through shallows both [Marjorie]323-marjorie and [Trafford]508-trafford took a paddle . [They]4191-they came to [the throat of [the gorge]4204-the gorge]4203-the throat of the gorge towards noon , and found strong flowing deep water between [its]4204-the gorge high purple cliffs . [All hands]4205-all hands had to paddle again , and it was only when [they]4191-they came to rest in [a pool]4206-a pool to eat a mid - day meal and afterwards to land upon a mossy corner for a stretch and a smoke , that [Marjorie]323-marjorie discovered the peculiar beauty of the rock about [them]4191-they . On the dull purplish - grey surfaces played the most extraordinary mist of luminous iridescence . It fascinated [her]323-marjorie . [Here]4725-here was [a land whose common substance had this gemlike opalescence]4208-a land whose common substance had this gemlike opalescence . But [her]323-marjorie attention was very soon withdrawn from these glancing splendours . [She]323-marjorie had had to put aside [her]323-marjorie veil to eat , and presently [she]323-marjorie felt the vividly painful stabs of the black - fly and discovered blood upon [her]323-marjorie face . A bigger fly , the size and something of the appearance of a small wasp , with an evil buzz , also assailed [her]323-marjorie and [Trafford]508-trafford . It was a bad corner for flies ; [the breeds even]4209-the breeds even were slapping [their]4209-the breeds even wrists and swearing under the torment , and [every one]4731-every one was glad to embark and push on up [the winding gorge]4211-the winding gorge . [It]4211-the winding gorge opened out for a time , and then [the wooded shores]4212-the wooded shores crept in again , and in another half - hour [they]4191-they saw ahead of [them]4191-they a long rush of foaming waters among tumbled rocks that poured down from a brimming , splashing line of light against the sky . [They]4191-they crossed [the river]4906-the river , ran [the canoes]4214-the canoes into an eddy under the shelter of a big stone and began to unload . [They]4191-they had reached [their]4191-they first portage . The rest of the first day was spent in packing and lugging first the cargoes and then [the canoes]4214-the canoes up through thickets and over boulders and across stretches of reindeer moss for the better part of two miles to [a camping ground about half - way up [the rapids]4217-the rapids]4216-a camping ground about half - way up the rapids . [Marjorie]323-marjorie and [Trafford]508-trafford tried to help with the carrying , but this evidently shocked and distressed [the men]984-the men too much , so [they]4191-they desisted and set to work cutting wood and gathering moss for the fires and bedding for [the camp]4219-the camp . When the iron stove was brought up [the man who had carried it]4220-the man who had carried it showed [them]4191-they how to put it up on stakes and start a fire in it , and then [Trafford]508-trafford went to [the river]4906-the river to get water , and [Marjorie]323-marjorie made a kind of flour cake in the frying - pan in the manner [an American woman from [the wilderness]4183-the wilderness]4222-an american woman from the wilderness had once shown [her]323-marjorie , and boiled water for tea . The twilight had deepened to night while [the men]984-the men were still stumbling up [the trail]4225-the trail with [the last two canoes]4226-the last two canoes . It gave [Marjorie]323-marjorie a curiously homeless feeling to stand there in the open with the sunset dying away below the black scrubby outlines of the treetops uphill to the northwest , and to realize the nearest roof was already a day 's toilsome journey away . The cool night breeze blew upon [her]323-marjorie bare face and arms — for now the insects had ceased from troubling and [she]323-marjorie had cast aside gloves and veil and turned up [her]323-marjorie sleeves to cook — and the air was full of the tumult of [the rapids]4217-the rapids tearing seaward over the rocks below . Struggling through the bushes towards [her]323-marjorie was [an immense , headless quadruped with unsteady legs and hesitating paces]4228-an immense , headless quadruped with unsteady legs and hesitating paces , [two of [the men carrying the last canoe]4230-the men carrying the last canoe]4229-two of the men carrying the last canoe . [Two others]4231-two others were now assisting [Trafford]508-trafford to put up [the little tent that was to shelter [her]323-marjorie]4232-the little tent that was to shelter her , and [the fifth]4233-the fifth was kneeling beside [her]323-marjorie very solemnly and respectfully cutting slices of bacon for [her]323-marjorie to fry . The air was very sweet , and [she]323-marjorie wished [she]323-marjorie could sleep not in [the tent]4234-the tent but under the open sky . It was queer , [she]323-marjorie thought , how much of the wrappings of civilization had slipped from them already . Every day of the journey from [London]17-london had released them or deprived [them]4235-them — [she]323-marjorie hardly knew which — of a multitude of petty comforts and easy accessibilities . The afternoon toil uphill intensified the effect of having clambered up out of things — to this loneliness , this twilight openness , this simplicity . [The men]984-the men ate apart at a fire [they]984-the men made for [themselves]984-the men , and after [Trafford]508-trafford and [Marjorie]323-marjorie had supped on damper , bacon and tea , [he]508-trafford smoked . [They]984-the men were both too healthily tired to talk very much . There was no moon but a frosty brilliance of stars , the air which had been hot and sultry at mid - day grew keen and penetrating , and after [she]323-marjorie had made [him]508-trafford tell [her]323-marjorie the names of constellations [she]323-marjorie had forgotten , [she]323-marjorie suddenly perceived the wisdom of [the tent]4234-the tent , went into it — it was sweet and wonderful with sprigs of the Labrador tea - shrub — undressed , and had hardly rolled [herself]323-marjorie up into a cocoon of blankets before [she]323-marjorie was fast asleep . [She]323-marjorie was awakened by a blaze of sunshine pouring into [the tent]4234-the tent , a smell of fried bacon and [Trafford]508-trafford 's voice telling [her]323-marjorie to get up . " [They]984-the men 've gone on with the first loads , "[508-trafford] [he]508-trafford said . " Get up , wrap [yourself]323-marjorie in a blanket , and come and bathe in [the river]4906-the river . It 's as cold as ice . "[323-marjorie] [She]323-marjorie blinked at [him]508-trafford . " Are n't [you]508-trafford stiff ? "[508-trafford] [she]323-marjorie asked . " [I]323-marjorie was stiffer before [I]323-marjorie bathed , "[323-marjorie] [he]508-trafford said . [She]323-marjorie took the tin [he]508-trafford offered [her]323-marjorie . ( [They]4239-we were n't to see china cups again for a year . ) " It 's [woman]2467-woman 's work getting tea , "[508-trafford] [she]323-marjorie said as [she]323-marjorie drank . " [You]323-marjorie ca n't be a squaw all at once , "[323-marjorie] said [Trafford]508-trafford . After [Marjorie]323-marjorie had taken [her]323-marjorie dip , dried roughly behind a bush , twisted [her]323-marjorie hair into a pigtail and coiled it under [her]323-marjorie hat , [she]323-marjorie amused [herself]323-marjorie and [Trafford]508-trafford as [they]4239-we clambered up through rocks and willows to [the tent]4234-the tent again by cataloguing [her]323-marjorie apparatus of bath and toilette at [Sussex Square]175-sussex square and tracing just when and how [she]323-marjorie had parted from each item on the way to [this place]5121-this place . " But [I]323-marjorie say ! "[323-marjorie] [she]323-marjorie cried , with a sudden , sharp note of dismay , " [we]4239-we have n't soap ! This is [our]4239-we last cake almost . [I]508-trafford never thought of soap . "[508-trafford] " Nor [I]508-trafford , "[508-trafford] said [Trafford]508-trafford . [He]508-trafford spoke again presently . " [We]4239-we do n't turn back for soap , "[323-marjorie] [he]508-trafford said . " [We]4239-we do n't turn back for anything , "[323-marjorie] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " Still — [I]508-trafford did n't count on a soapless winter . "[508-trafford] " [I]508-trafford 'll manage something , "[508-trafford] said [Trafford]508-trafford , a little doubtfully . " Trust [a chemist]5941-a chemist .... "[508-trafford] That day [they]4242-they finished [the portage]4243-the portage and came out upon [a wide lake]4244-a wide lake with sloping shores and a distant view of [snow - topped mountains]4245-snow - topped mountains , [a lake so shallow that at times [their]4242-they loaded canoes scraped on the glaciated rock below and [they]4242-they had to alter [their]4242-they course]4246-a lake so shallow that at times their loaded canoes scraped on the glaciated rock below and they had to alter their course . [They]4242-they camped in a lurid sunset ; the night was warm and mosquitoes were troublesome , and towards morning came a thunderstorm and wind and rain . The dawn broke upon a tearing race of waves and a wild drift of slanting rain sweeping across [the lake]5329-the lake before a gale . [Marjorie]323-marjorie peered out at this as [one]675-one peers out under the edge of an umbrella . It was manifestly impossible to go on , and [they]4242-they did nothing that day but run up [a canvas shelter for [the men]984-the men]4249-a canvas shelter for the men and shift [the tent]4234-the tent behind a thicket of trees out of the full force of the wind . [The men]984-the men squatted stoically , and smoked and yarned . Everything got coldly wet , and for the most part [the Traffords]425-the traffords sat under the tent and stared blankly at this summer day in [Labrador]190-labrador . " Now , "[508-trafford] said [Trafford]508-trafford , " [we]4242-they ought to begin talking . "[323-marjorie] " There 's nothing much to do else , "[508-trafford] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " Only one ca n't begin , "[508-trafford] said [Trafford]508-trafford . [He]508-trafford was silent for a time . " [We]4242-they 're getting out of things , "[508-trafford] [he]508-trafford said .... The next day began with a fine drizzle through which the sun broke suddenly about ten o'clock . [They]4242-they made a start at once , and got a good dozen miles up [the lake]5329-the lake before it was necessary to camp again . Both [Marjorie]323-marjorie and [Trafford]508-trafford felt stiff and weary and uncomfortable all day , and secretly a little doubtful now of [their]4242-they own endurance . [They]4242-they camped on [an island on turf amidst slippery rocks]4254-an island on turf amidst slippery rocks , and the next day were in [a foaming difficult river]4255-a foaming difficult river again , with glittering shallows that obliged [every one]4731-every one to get out at times to wade and push . All through the afternoon [they]4242-they were greatly beset by flies . And so [they]4242-they worked [their]4242-they way on through a third days ' journey towards [the silent inland of [Labrador]190-labrador]4257-the silent inland of labrador . Day followed day of toilsome and often tedious travel ; [they]4242-they fought rapids , [they]4242-they waited while [the men]984-the men stumbled up long portages under vast loads , going and returning , [they]4242-they camped and discussed difficulties and alternatives . The flies sustained an unrelenting persecution , until faces were scarred in spite of veils and smoke fires , until wrists and necks were swollen and the blood in a fever . As [they]4242-they got higher and higher towards [the central plateau]4259-the central plateau , the mid - day heat increased and the nights grew colder , until [they]4242-they would find [themselves]4242-they toiling , wet with perspiration , over rocks that sheltered a fringe of ice beneath [their]4242-they shadows . The first fatigues and lassitudes , the shrinking from cold water , the ache of muscular effort , gave place to a tougher and tougher endurance ; skin seemed to have lost half its capacity for pain without losing a tithe of its discrimination , muscles attained a steely resilience ; [they]4242-they were getting seasoned . " [I]508-trafford do n't feel philosophical , "[508-trafford] said [Trafford]508-trafford , " but [I]1016-the man feel well . "[1016-the man] " [We]4242-they 're getting out of things . "[508-trafford] " Suppose [we]4242-they are getting out of [our]4242-they problems ! ... "[1016-the man] One day as [they]4242-they paddled across [a mile - long pool]4260-a mile - long pool , [they]4242-they saw three bears prowling in single file high up on [the hillside]4261-the hillside . " Look , "[508-trafford] said [the man]1016-the man , and pointed with [his]1016-the man paddle at [the big , soft , furry black shapes , magnified and startling in the clear air]4263-the big , soft , furry black shapes , magnified and startling in the clear air . [All the canoes]4264-all the canoes rippled to a stop , [the men , at first still]4265-the men , at first still , whispered softly . [One]675-one passed a gun to [Trafford]508-trafford , who hesitated and looked at [Marjorie]323-marjorie . The air of tranquil assurance about [these three huge loafing monsters]4267-these three huge loafing monsters had a queer effect on [Marjorie]323-marjorie 's mind . [They]4267-these three huge loafing monsters made [her]323-marjorie feel that [they]4267-these three huge loafing monsters were at [home]810-home and that [she]323-marjorie was [an intruder]4269-an intruder . [She]323-marjorie had never in [her]323-marjorie life seen any big wild animals except in a menagerie . [She]323-marjorie had developed a sort of unconscious belief that all big wild animals were in menageries nowadays , and this spectacle of beasts entirely at large startled [her]323-marjorie . There was never a bar between [these creatures]4270-these creatures , [she]323-marjorie felt , and [[her]323-marjorie sleeping self]4271-her sleeping self . [They]4270-these creatures might , [she]323-marjorie thought , do any desperate thing to [feeble men and women who came [their]4270-these creatures way]4272-feeble men and women who came their way . " Shall [I]323-marjorie take a shot ? "[323-marjorie] asked [Trafford]508-trafford . " No , "[323-marjorie] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie , pervaded by the desire for mutual toleration . " Let [them]4273-the big brutes be . "[508-trafford] [The big brutes]4273-the big brutes disappeared in a gully , reappeared , came out against the skyline one by one and vanished . " Too long a shot , "[508-trafford] said [Trafford]508-trafford , handing back the gun .... [Their]4273-the big brutes journey lasted altogether a month . Never once did [they]4273-the big brutes come upon [any human being]844-any human being save [themselves]4273-the big brutes , though in one place [they]4273-the big brutes passed the poles — for the most part overthrown — of [an old Indian encampment]4275-an old indian encampment . But this desolation was by no means lifeless . [They]4273-the big brutes saw great quantities of waterbirds , geese , divers , Arctic partridge and the like , [they]4273-the big brutes became familiar with the banshee cry of the loon . [They]4273-the big brutes lived very largely on geese and partridge . Then for a time about a string of [lakes]4276-lakes , [the country]613-the country was alive with migrating deer going south , and [the men]984-the men found traces of a wolf . [They]4273-the big brutes killed six caribou , and stayed to skin and cut [them]4273-the big brutes up and dry the meat to replace the bacon [they]4273-the big brutes had consumed , caught , fried and ate great quantities of trout , and became accustomed to the mysterious dance of the northern lights as the sunset afterglow faded . Everywhere , except in [the river gorges]4279-the river gorges , [the country]613-the country displayed the low hummocky lines and [tarn - like pools of intensely glaciated land]4281-tarn - like pools of intensely glaciated land ; everywhere [it]613-the country was carpeted with reindeer moss growing upon peat and variegated by bushes of flowering , sweet - smelling Labrador tea . In places this was starred with little harebells and diversified by tussocks of heather and rough grass , and over the rocks trailed delicate dwarf shrubs and a very pretty and fragrant pink - flowered plant of which neither [she]4282-she nor [Trafford]508-trafford knew the name . There was an astonishing amount of wild fruit , raspberries , cranberries , and a white kind of strawberry that was very delightful . The weather , after its first outbreak , remained brightly serene .... And at last it seemed fit to [Trafford]508-trafford to halt and choose [[his]508-trafford winter quarters]4283-his winter quarters . [He]508-trafford chose a place on [the side of [a low , razor - hacked rocky mountain ridge]4285-a low , razor - hacked rocky mountain ridge]4284-the side of a low , razor - hacked rocky mountain ridge , about fifty feet above [the river]4906-the river — which had now dwindled to [a thirty - foot stream]4287-a thirty - foot stream . [[His]508-trafford site]4288-his site was near a tributary rivulet that gave convenient water , in a kind of lap that sheltered between two rocky knees , each bearing thickets of willow and balsam . Not a dozen miles away from [them]984-the men now [they]4273-the big brutes reckoned was [the Height of Land]4289-the height of land , the low watershed between [the waters that go to [the Atlantic]213-the atlantic and those that go to [Hudson 's Bay]214-hudson 's bay]4290-the waters that go to the atlantic and those that go to hudson 's bay . Close beside [the site]3880-the site [he]508-trafford had chosen a shelf of rock ran out and gave a glimpse up [the narrow rocky valley of [the Green River]212-the green river 's upper waters]4292-the narrow rocky valley of the green river 's upper waters and [a broad prospect of hill and tarn towards the south - east]4293-a broad prospect of hill and tarn towards the south - east . North and north - east of [them]984-the men [the country]613-the country rose to a line of low crests , with here and there a yellowing patch of last year 's snow , and across [the valley]4295-the valley were slopes covered in places by woods of stunted pine . [It]4296-it had an empty spaciousness of effect ; the one continually living thing seemed to be [the Green River]212-the green river , hurrying headlong , noisily , perpetually , in an eternal flight from this high desolation . Birds were rare here , and the insects that buzzed and shrilled and tormented among the rocks and willows in [the gorge]4204-the gorge came but sparingly up the slopes to [them]984-the men . " Here presently , "[508-trafford] said [Trafford]508-trafford , " [we]4273-the big brutes shall be in peace . "[323-marjorie] " [It]4296-it is very lonely , "[323-marjorie] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " The nearer to [God]249-god . "[508-trafford] " Think ! [Not one of [these hills]5943-these hills]5942-not one of these hills has ever had a name . "[508-trafford] " Well ? "[323-marjorie] " It might be in [some other planet]5944-some other planet . "[323-marjorie] " [Oh!—we'll]537-oh!—we'll christen [them]984-the men . That shall be [Marjorie Ridge]215-marjorie ridge , and that [Rag Valley]216-rag valley . [This space]5945-this space shall be — oh ! [Bayswater]217-bayswater ! Before [we]4273-the big brutes 've done with [it]5945-this space , [this place]5121-this place and every feature of [it]5121-this place will be as familiar as [Sussex Square]175-sussex square . More so,—for half [the houses]2226-the houses there would be stranger to [us]4273-the big brutes , if [we]4273-the big brutes could see inside [them]2226-the houses , than anything in [this wilderness]5948-this wilderness .... As familiar , say — as [[your]5949-your drawing - room]5950-your drawing - room . That 's better . "[539-noyes] [Marjorie]323-marjorie made no answer , but [her]323-marjorie eyes went from the reindeer moss and scrub and thickets of the foreground to [the low rocky ridges that bounded the view north and east of [them]4299-them]4298-the low rocky ridges that bounded the view north and east of them . The scattered boulders , the tangles of wood , [the barren upper slopes]4300-the barren upper slopes , the dust - soiled survivals of the winter 's snowfall , all contributed to an effect at once carelessly desert and hopelessly untidy . [She]323-marjorie looked westward , and [her]323-marjorie memory was full of interminable streaming rapids , wastes of ice - striated rocks , tiresome struggles through woods and wild , wide stretches of tundra and tarn , trackless and treeless , infinitely desolate . It seemed to [her]323-marjorie that [the sea coast]4301-the sea coast was but a step from [London]17-london and ten thousand miles away from [her]323-marjorie . [The men]984-the men had engaged to build the framework of [hut and store shed]4303-hut and store shed before returning , and to this under [Trafford]508-trafford 's direction [they]984-the men now set [themselves]984-the men . [They]984-the men were all half - breeds , mingling with [Indian with Scottish or French blood]4304-indian with scottish or french blood , [sober and experienced men]4305-sober and experienced men . Three were named [Mackenzie]538-mackenzie , [two brothers]4306-two brothers and [a cousin]583-a cousin , and another , [Raymond Noyes]539-noyes , was [a relation and acquaintance of [that [George Elson]509-hubbard who was with [Wallace]509-hubbard and [Leonidas Hubbard]509-hubbard , and afterwards guided [Mrs. Hubbard]509-hubbard]509-hubbard in [[her]509-hubbard crossing of [Labrador]190-labrador]4309-her crossing of labrador]4308-a relation and acquaintance of that george elson who was with wallace and leonidas hubbard , and afterwards guided mrs. hubbard in her crossing of labrador . [The fifth]4233-the fifth was [a boy of eighteen named [Lean]540-lean]4311-a boy of eighteen named lean . [They]984-the men were all familiar with the idea of summer travel in [this country]1464-this country ; quite a number , a score or so that is to say , of [adventurous people]4313-adventurous people , including [three or four women]4314-three or four women , had ventured far in the wake of [the Hubbards]541-the hubbards into [these great wildernesses]4315-these great wildernesses during the decade that followed that first tragic experiment in which [Hubbard]509-hubbard died . But that [any one not of Indian or Esquimaux blood]4316-any one not of indian or esquimaux blood should propose to face out [the Labrador]190-labrador winter was a new thing to [them]984-the men . [They]984-the men were really very sceptical at the outset whether [these two highly civilized - looking people]4317-these two highly civilized - looking people would ever get up to [the Height of Land]219-the height of land at all , and it was still with manifest incredulity that [they]984-the men set about the building of [the hut]4318-the hut and the construction of the sleeping bunks for which [they]984-the men had brought up planking . A stream of speculative talk had flowed along beside [Marjorie]323-marjorie and [Trafford]508-trafford ever since [they]984-the men had entered [the Green River]212-the green river ; and it did n't so much come to an end as get cut off at last by the necessity of [their]984-the men departure . [Noyes]539-noyes would stand , holding a hammer and staring at the narrow little berth [he]539-noyes was fixing together . " [You]323-marjorie 'll not sleep in this , "[323-marjorie] [he]539-noyes said . " [I]323-marjorie will , "[323-marjorie] replied [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " [You]323-marjorie 'll come back with [us]984-the men . "[323-marjorie] " Not [me]323-marjorie . "[323-marjorie] " There 'll be wolves come and howl . "[323-marjorie] " Let 'em . "[323-marjorie] " [They]5951-they 'll come right up to the door here . [Winter]542-winter makes ['em]5952-'em hidjus bold . "[539-noyes] [Marjorie]323-marjorie shrugged [her]323-marjorie shoulders . " It 's that cold [I]539-noyes 've known [a man]837-a man have [his]837-a man nose froze while [he]837-a man lay in bed , "[539-noyes] said [Noyes]539-noyes . " Up here ? "[539-noyes] " Down [the coast]5954-the coast . But [they]5951-they say it 's ' most as cold up here . [Many]5955-many 's [the man]1016-the man it 's starved and froze . "[539-noyes] ... [He]539-noyes and [[his]539-noyes companions]4319-his companions told stories,—very circumstantial and pitiful stories , of Indian disasters . [They]4320-they were all tales of weariness and starvation , of the cessation of food , because the fishing gave out , because the caribou did not migrate by the customary route , because [the man of a family group]4321-the man of a family group broke [his]4321-the man of a family group wrist , and then of the start of all or [some of the party to [the coast]5954-the coast]4322-some of the party to the coast to get help and provisions , of [the straining , starving fugitives caught by blizzards , losing the track]4324-the straining , starving fugitives caught by blizzards , losing the track , devouring small vermin raw , gnawing [their]4324-the straining , starving fugitives caught by blizzards , losing the track own skin garments until [they]4324-the straining , starving fugitives caught by blizzards , losing the track toiled half - naked in the snow,—becoming cannibals , becoming delirious , lying down to die . Once there was an epidemic of influenza , and [three families of seven and twenty people]4325-three families of seven and twenty people just gave up and starved and died in [[their]4325-three families of seven and twenty people lodges]4326-their lodges , and were found , still partly frozen , a patient , pitiful company , by [trappers]4327-trappers in the spring .... Such [they]4327-trappers said , were the common things that happened in a Labrador winter . Did [the Traffords]425-the traffords wish to run such risks ? A sort of propagandist enthusiasm grew up in [the men]984-the men . [They]984-the men felt it incumbent upon [them]984-the men to persuade [the Traffords]425-the traffords to return . [They]984-the men reasoned with [them]425-the traffords rather as one does with [wilful children]4329-wilful children . [They]984-the men tried to remind [them]425-the traffords of the delights and securities of [the world]589-the world [they]425-the traffords were deserting . [Noyes]539-noyes drew fancy pictures of the pleasures of [London]17-london by way of contrast to the bitter days before [them]984-the men . " [You]5957-you 've got everything there , everything . Suppose [you]5957-you feel a bit ill , [you]5957-you go out , and [every block]5958-every block there 's [a drug store]5959-a drug store got everything — all the new rem'dies — p'raps twenty , thirty sorts of rem'dy . Lit up , nice . And [chaps in collars]5960-chaps in collars — like [gentlemen]5961-gentlemen . Or [you]5957-you feel a bit dully and [you]5957-you go into [the streets]1539-the streets and there 's [people]631-people . Why ! when [I]323-marjorie was in [New York]70-new york [I]323-marjorie used to spend hours looking at [the people]1134-the people . Hours ! And everything lit up , too . Sky signs ! Readin ' everywhere . [You]5957-you can spend hours and hours in [New York]70-new york — — "[323-marjorie] " [London]17-london , "[539-noyes] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " Well , [London]17-london — just going about and reading the things [they]1134-the people stick up . Every blamed sort of thing . Or [you]5957-you say , let 's go somewhere . Let 's go out and be a bit lively . See ? Up [you]5957-you get on [a car]919-a car and there [you]5957-you are ! [Great big restaurants]5966-great big restaurants , blazing with lights , and [you]5957-you ca n't think of a thing to eat [they]5966-great big restaurants have n't got . Waiters all round [you]5957-you , dressed tremendous , fair asking [you]5957-you to have more . Or [you]5957-you say , let 's go to [a theatre]5967-a theatre . Very likely , "[539-noyes] said [Noyes]539-noyes , letting [his]539-noyes imagination soar , " [you]5957-you order up one of these automobillies . "[508-trafford] " By telephone , "[539-noyes] helped [Trafford]508-trafford . " By telephone , "[539-noyes] confirmed [Noyes]539-noyes . "[540-lean] Why had [they]4331-they come [here]4725-here ? [None of [the men]984-the men]4333-none of the men were clear about that . [Marjorie]323-marjorie and [Trafford]508-trafford would overhear [them]984-the men discussing this question at [their]984-the men fire night after night ; [they]984-the men seemed to talk of nothing else . [They]984-the men indulged in the boldest hypotheses , even in the theory that [Trafford]508-trafford knew of deposits of diamonds and gold , and would trust [no one]4871-no one but [[his]508-trafford wife]848-his wife with the secret . [They]984-the men seemed also attracted by the idea that [[our]4337-our two young people]2527-our two young people had " done something . "[540-lean] [Lean]540-lean , with memories of some tattered sixpenny novel that had drifted into [his]540-lean hands from [England]9-england , had even some notion of an elopement , of [a pursuing husband]4339-a pursuing husband or [a vindictive wife]4340-a vindictive wife . [He]540-lean was young and romantic , but it seemed incredible [he]540-lean should suggest that [Marjorie]323-marjorie was [a royal princess]4341-a royal princess . Yet there were moments when [his]540-lean manner betrayed a more than personal respect .... One night after a hard day 's portage [Mackenzie]538-mackenzie was inspired by a brilliant idea . " [They]984-the men got [no children]5971-no children , "[540-lean] [he]540-lean said , in a hoarse , exceptionally audible whisper . " It worries [them]984-the men . "[323-marjorie] " [I]323-marjorie ca n't stand that , "[323-marjorie] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " It touches [my]538-mackenzie pride . [I]538-mackenzie 've stood a good deal . "[394-trafford] " [We]984-the men want to be here , "[984-the men] shouted [Trafford]394-trafford to [their]984-the men listening pause . [Their]984-the men silence was incredulous . " [We]984-the men wanted to be alone together . There was too much — over there — too much everything . [He]538-mackenzie could not understand how there could be too much of anything . It was beyond [a trapper]4344-a trapper 's philosophy . " Come back with [[us]984-the men [sir]4762-sir]5976-us sir , "[539-noyes] said [Noyes]539-noyes . " [You]4762-sir 'll weary of it .... " [I]539-noyes do n't care to leave [ye]4762-sir , "[539-noyes] [he]539-noyes said , and made a sort of byword of it that served when there was nothing else to say . [He]539-noyes made it almost [his]539-noyes last words . [He]539-noyes turned back for another handclasp as the others under [their]984-the men light returning packs were filing down [the hill]4345-the hill . " [I]394-trafford do n't care to leave [ye]4762-sir , "[394-trafford] [he]539-noyes said . " Good luck ! "[539-noyes] said [Trafford]394-trafford . " [You]323-marjorie 'll need it , "[539-noyes] said [Noyes]539-noyes , and looked at [Marjorie]323-marjorie very gravely and intently before [he]539-noyes turned about and marched off after [[his]539-noyes fellows]4346-his fellows .... Both [Marjorie]323-marjorie and [Trafford]394-trafford felt a queer emotion , a sense of loss and desertion , a swelling in the throat , as that file of [men]600-men receded over [the rocky slopes]4348-the rocky slopes , went down into a dip , reappeared presently small and remote cresting another spur , going on towards the little wood that hid [the head of the rapids]4349-the head of the rapids . [They]984-the men halted for a moment on [the edge of the wood]4350-the edge of the wood and looked back , then turned again one by one and melted stride by stride into the trees . [Noyes]539-noyes was the last to go . [He]539-noyes stood , in an attitude that spoke as plainly as words , " [I]539-noyes do n't care to leave [ye]5978-ye . "[539-noyes] Something white waved and flickered ; [he]539-noyes had whipped out the letters [they]984-the men had given [him]539-noyes for [England]9-england , and [he]539-noyes was waving them . Then , as if by an effort , [he]539-noyes set [himself]539-noyes to follow [the others]968-the others , and [the two still watchers on the height above]4352-the two still watchers on the height above saw [him]539-noyes no more . [Marjorie]323-marjorie and [Trafford]394-trafford walked slowly back to [the hut]4318-the hut . " There is much to do before the weather breaks , "[539-noyes] [he]539-noyes said , ending a thoughtful silence . " Then [we]4354-we can sit inside there and talk about the things [we]4354-we need to talk about . "[539-noyes] [He]539-noyes added awkwardly : " Since [we]4354-we started , there has been so much to hold the attention . [I]539-noyes remember a mood — an immense despair . [I]539-noyes feel it 's still somewhere at the back of things , waiting to be dealt with . It 's [our]4354-we essential fact . But meanwhile [we]4354-we 've been busy , looking at fresh things . "[539-noyes] [He]539-noyes paused . " Now it will be different perhaps .... "[394-trafford] For nearly four weeks indeed [they]4354-we were occupied very closely , and crept into [[their]4354-we bunks]4355-their bunks at night as tired as wholesome animals who drop to sleep . At any time the weather might break ; already there had been two overcast days and a frowning conference of clouds in [the north]4356-the north . When at last storms began [they]4354-we knew there would be nothing for it but to keep in [the hut]4318-the hut until [the world]589-the world froze up . There was much to do to [the hut]4318-the hut . The absence of anything but stunted and impoverished timber and the limitation of time , had forbidden [a log hut]4360-a log hut , and [[their]4354-we home]4361-their home was really only a double framework , rammed tight between inner and outer frame with a mixture of earth and boughs and twigs of willow , pine and balsam . The floor was hammered earth carpeted with balsam twigs and a caribou skin . Outside and within wall and roof were faced with coarse canvas — that was [Trafford]394-trafford 's idea — and [[their]4354-we bunks]4355-their bunks occupied [two sides of [the hut]4318-the hut]4363-two sides of the hut . Heating was done by the sheet - iron stove [they]4354-we had brought with [them]4354-we , and the smoke was carried out to the roof by a thin sheet - iron pipe which had come up outside a roll of canvas . [They]4354-we had made the roof with about the pitch of a Swiss châlet , and [it]4365-it was covered with nailed waterproof canvas , held down by a large number of big lumps of stone . Much of the canvassing still remained to do when [the men]984-the men went down , and then [the Traffords]425-the traffords used every scrap of packing - paper and newspaper that had come up with [them]425-the traffords and was not needed for lining the bunks in covering any crack or join in the canvas wall . Two decadent luxuries , a rubber bath and two rubber hot - water bottles , hung behind the door . [They]4367-they were almost the only luxuries . Kettles and pans and some provisions stood on a shelf over the stove ; there was also a sort of recess cupboard in the opposite corner , reserve clothes were in canvas trunks under the bunks , [they]4354-we kept [their]4354-we immediate supply of wood under the eaves just outside the door , and there was a big can of water between stove and door . When the winter came [they]4354-we would have to bring in ice from [the stream]4368-the stream . This was [[their]4354-we home]4361-their home . [The tent that had sheltered [Marjorie]323-marjorie on the way up]4370-the tent that had sheltered marjorie on the way up was erected close to [this hut]4371-this hut to serve as [a rude scullery and outhouse]4372-a rude scullery and outhouse , and [they]4354-we also made a long , roughly thatched roof with a canvas cover , supported on stakes , to shelter the rest of [the stores]4373-the stores . The stuff in tins and cases and jars [they]4354-we left on the ground under this ; the rest — the flour , candles , bacon , dried caribou beef , and so forth , [they]4354-we hung , as [they]4354-we hoped , out of the reach of any prowling beast . And finally and most important was the wood pile . This [they]4354-we accumulated to the north and east of [the hut]4318-the hut , and all day long with a sort of ant - like perseverance Trafford added to it from the thickets below . Once or twice , however , tempted by the appearance of birds , [he]4375-he went shooting , and one day [he]4375-he got five geese that [they]4354-we spent a day upon , plucking , cleaning , boiling and putting up in all [their]4354-we store of empty cans , letting the fat float and solidify on the top to preserve this addition to [their]4354-we provision until the advent of the frost rendered all other preservatives unnecessary . [They]4354-we also tried to catch trout down in [the river below]4376-the river below , but though [they]4354-we saw many fish the catch was less than a dozen . It was a discovery to [both of [them]4354-we]4377-both of them to find how companionable these occupations were , how much more side by side [they]4354-we could be amateurishly cleaning out a goose and disputing about [its]4378-its cooking , than [they]4354-we had ever contrived to be in [Sussex Square]175-sussex square . " These things are so infernally interesting , "[394-trafford] said [Trafford]394-trafford , surveying the row of miscellaneous cans upon the stove [he]4375-he had packed with disarticulated goose . " But [we]4354-we did n't come here to picnic . All this is eating [us]4354-we up . [I]323-marjorie have a memory of some immense tragic purpose — — "[323-marjorie] " That tin 's boiling ! "[4375-he] screamed [Marjorie]323-marjorie sharply . [He]4375-he resumed [his]4375-he thread after an active interlude . " [We]4354-we 'll keep the wolf from the door , "[323-marjorie] [he]4375-he said . " Do n't talk of wolves ! "[323-marjorie] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " It is only when [men]600-men have driven away the wolf from the door — oh ! altogether away , that [they]600-men find despair in the sky ? [I]323-marjorie wonder — — "[323-marjorie] " What ? "[323-marjorie] asked [Marjorie]323-marjorie in [his]4375-he pause . " [I]323-marjorie wonder if there is nothing really in life but this , the food hunt and the love hunt . Is life just all hunger and need , and are [we]4354-we left with nothing — nothing at all — when these things are done ? ... [We]4354-we 're infernally uncomfortable [here]4725-here . "[323-marjorie] " Oh , nonsense ! "[323-marjorie] cried [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " Think of [your]4375-he carpets at [home]810-home ! Think of [the great , warm , beautiful house that was n't big enough!—And yet here]5982-the great , warm , beautiful house that was n't big enough!—and yet here , [we]4354-we 're happy . "[323-marjorie] " [We]4354-we are happy , "[323-marjorie] said [Marjorie]323-marjorie , struck by the thought . " Only — — "[323-marjorie] " Yes . "[323-marjorie] " [I]323-marjorie 'm afraid . And [I]323-marjorie long for [the children]1036-the children . And the wind nips . "[323-marjorie] " It may be those are good things for [us]4354-we . No ! This is just a lark as yet , [Marjorie]323-marjorie . It 's still fresh and full of distractions . The discomforts are amusing . Presently [we]4354-we 'll get used to it . Then [we]4354-we 'll talk out — what [we]4354-we have to talk out .... [I]323-marjorie say , would n't it keep and improve this goose of [ours]4354-we if [we]4354-we put in a little brandy ? "[323-marjorie] The weather broke at last . [One]675-one might say it smashed itself over [their]4380-they heads . There came an afternoon darkness swift and sudden , a wild gale and an icy sleet that gave place in the night to snow , so that [Trafford]394-trafford looked out next morning to see a maddening chaos of small white flakes , incredibly swift , against something that was neither darkness nor light . Even with the door but partly ajar a cruelty of cold put its claw within , set everything that was moveable swaying and clattering , and made [Marjorie]323-marjorie hasten shuddering to heap fresh logs upon the fire . Once or twice [Trafford]394-trafford went out to inspect [tent]4381-tent and roof and [store - shed]4382-store - shed , several times wrapped to the nose [he]4383-he battled [his]4383-he way for fresh wood , and for the rest of the blizzard [they]4380-they kept to [the hut]4318-the hut . It was slumberously stuffy , but comfortingly full of flavours of tobacco and food . There were two days of intermission and a day of gusts and icy sleet again , turning with one extraordinary clap of thunder to a wild downpour of dancing lumps of ice , and then a night when it seemed all [Labrador]190-labrador , earth and sky together , was in hysterical protest against inconceivable wrongs . And then the break was over ; the annual freezing - up was accomplished , winter had established itself , the snowfall moderated and ceased , and [an ice - bound world]4385-an ice - bound world shone white and sunlit under a cloudless sky . Through all that time [they]4380-they got no further with the great discussion for which [they]4380-they had faced that solitude . [They]4380-they attempted beginnings . " Where had [we]4354-we got to when [we]4354-we left [England]9-england ? "[323-marjorie] cried [Marjorie]323-marjorie . " [You]394-trafford could n't work , [you]394-trafford could n't rest — [you]394-trafford hated [our]4354-we life . "[4386-he] " Yes , [I]4386-he know . [I]4386-he had a violent hatred of the lives [we]4354-we were leading . [I]4386-he thought — [we]4354-we had to get away . To think .... But things do n't leave [us]4354-we alone here . "[4386-he] [He]4386-he covered [his]4386-he face with [his]4386-he hands . " Why did [we]4354-we come here ? "[4386-he] [he]4386-he asked . " [You]4386-he wanted — to get out of things . "[323-marjorie] " Yes . But with [you]4386-he .... Have [we]4354-we , after all , got out of things at all ? [I]4386-he said coming up , perhaps [we]4354-we were leaving [our]4354-we own problem behind . In exchange for other problems — old problems [men]600-men have had before . [We]4354-we 've got nearer necessity ; that 's all . Things press on [us]4354-we just as much . There 's nothing more fundamental in wild nature , nothing profounder — only something earlier . [One]675-one does n't get out of life by going here or there .... But [I]4386-he wanted to get [you]4386-he away — from all things that had such a hold on [you]4386-he .... "[4386-he] When [one]675-one lies awake at nights , then [one]675-one seems to get down into things .... " [He]4386-he went to the door , opened it , and stood looking out . Against a wan daylight the snow was falling noiselessly and steadily . "[4386-he] Everything goes on , " [he]4386-he said .... "[4386-he] Relentlessly .... " That was as far as [they]5986-they had got when the storms ceased and [they]5986-they came out again into an air inexpressibly fresh and sharp and sweet , and into a world blindingly clean and golden white under the rays of the morning sun . "[323-marjorie] [We]4389-we will build a fire out here , " said [Marjorie]323-marjorie ; "[4386-he] make a great pile . There is no reason at all why [we]4389-we should n't live outside all through the day in such weather as this . " One morning [Trafford]394-trafford found the footmarks of some catlike creature in the snow near the bushes where [he]4386-he was accustomed to get firewood ; [they]5986-they led away very plainly up [the hill]4345-the hill , and after breakfast [he]4386-he took [his]4386-he knife and rifle and snowshoes and went after the lynx — for that [he]4386-he decided the animal must be . There was no urgent reason why [he]4386-he should want to kill a lynx , unless perhaps that killing [it]5988-it made [the store shed]5989-the store shed a trifle safer ; but it was the first trail of any living thing for many days ; it promised excitement ; some primordial instinct perhaps urged [him]4386-he . The morning was a little overcast , and very cold between the gleams of wintry sunshine . "[4390-dear wife] Good - bye , [dear wife]4390-dear wife ! " [he]0-i said , and then as [she]4390-dear wife remembered afterwards came back a dozen yards to kiss [her]4390-dear wife . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'll not be long , " [he]0-i said . "[0-i] The beast 's prowling , and if it does n't get wind of [me]0-i [I]0-i ought to find it in an hour . " [He]0-i hesitated for a moment . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'll not be long , " [he]0-i repeated , and [she]4390-dear wife had an instant 's wonder whether [he]0-i hid from [her]4390-dear wife the same dread of loneliness that [she]4390-dear wife concealed . Or perhaps [he]0-i only knew [her]4390-dear wife secret . Up among the tumbled rocks [he]0-i turned , and [she]4390-dear wife was still watching [him]0-i . "[0-i] Good - bye ! " [he]0-i cried and waved , and the willow thickets closed about [him]0-i . [She]4390-dear wife forced [herself]4390-dear wife to the petty duties of the day , made up the fire from the pile [he]0-i had left for [her]4390-dear wife , set water to boil , put [the hut]4318-the hut in order , brought out sheets and blankets to air and set [herself]4390-dear wife to wash up . [She]4390-dear wife wished [she]4390-dear wife had been able to go with [him]0-i . The sky cleared presently , and the low December sun lit all [the world]589-the world about [her]4390-dear wife , but it left [her]4390-dear wife spirit desolate . [She]4390-dear wife did not expect [him]0-i to return until mid - day , and [she]4390-dear wife sat [herself]4390-dear wife down on a log before the fire to darn a pair of socks as well as [she]4390-dear wife could . For a time this unusual occupation held [her]4390-dear wife attention and then [her]4390-dear wife hands became slow and at last inactive , and [she]4390-dear wife fell into reverie . [She]4390-dear wife thought at first of [[her]4390-dear wife children]5929-her children and what [they]5929-her children might be doing , in [England]9-england across there to [the east]5993-the east it would be about five hours later , four o'clock in the afternoon , and [the children]1036-the children would be coming [home]810-home through the warm muggy [London]17-london sunshine with [Fraulein Otto]544-fraulein otto to tea . [She]4390-dear wife wondered if [they]5929-her children had the proper clothes , if [they]5929-her children were well ; were [they]5929-her children perhaps quarrelling or being naughty or skylarking gaily across [the Park]1122-the park . Of course [Fraulein Otto]544-fraulein otto was all right , quite to be trusted , absolutely trustworthy , and [[their]5929-her children grandmother]5997-their grandmother would watch for a flushed face or an irrational petulance or any of the little signs that herald trouble with more than [a mother]4834-a mother 's instinctive alertness . No need to worry about [the children]1036-the children , no need whatever [....]545-.... [The world of [London]17-london]6000-the world of london opened out behind these thoughts ; it was so queer to think that [she]4390-dear wife was in almost the same latitude as the busy bright traffic of the autumn season in [Kensington Gore]72-kensington gore ; that away there in [ten thousand cleverly furnished drawing - rooms]6001-ten thousand cleverly furnished drawing - rooms the ringing tea things were being set out for the rustling advent of [smart callers]6002-smart callers and the quick leaping gossip . And there would be all sorts of cakes and little things ; for a while [her]4390-dear wife mind ran on cakes and little things , and [she]4390-dear wife thought in particular whether it was n't time to begin cooking .... Not yet . What was it [she]4390-dear wife had been thinking about ? Ah ! [the Solomonsons]499-the solomonsons and [the Capeses]546-the capeses and [the Bernards]530-the bernards and [the Carmels]256-the carmels and [the Lees]460-the lees . Would [they]1036-the children talk of [her]4390-dear wife and [Trafford]394-trafford ? It would be strange to go back to it all . Would [they]1036-the children go back to it all ? [She]4390-dear wife found [herself]4390-dear wife thinking intently of [Trafford]394-trafford . What [a fine human being]6003-a fine human being [he]6003-a fine human being was ! And how touchingly human ! The thoughts of [his]6003-a fine human being moments of irritation , [his]6003-a fine human being baffled silences , filled [her]4390-dear wife with a wild passion of tenderness . [She]4390-dear wife had disappointed [him]6003-a fine human being ; all that life failed to satisfy [him]6003-a fine human being . [Dear master of [her]4390-dear wife life]6004-dear master of her life ! what was it [he]6003-a fine human being needed ? [She]4390-dear wife too was n't satisfied with life , but while [she]4390-dear wife had been able to assuage [herself]4390-dear wife with a perpetual series of petty excitements , theatres , new books and [new people]6005-new people , meetings , movements , dinners , shows , [he]6003-a fine human being had grown to an immense discontent . [He]6003-a fine human being had most of the things [men]600-men sought , wealth , respect , love , [children]1961-children .... So many men might have blunted [their]600-men heart - ache with — adventures . There were [pretty women]6008-pretty women , [clever women]6009-clever women , [unoccupied women]6010-unoccupied women . [She]4390-dear wife felt [she]4390-dear wife would n't have minded — much — if it made [him]6003-a fine human being happy .... It was so wonderful [he]6003-a fine human being loved [her]4390-dear wife still .... It was n't that [he]6003-a fine human being lacked occupation ; on the whole [he]6003-a fine human being overworked . [His]6003-a fine human being business interests were big and wide . Ought [he]6003-a fine human being to go into politics ? Why was it that the researches that had held [him]6003-a fine human being once , could hold [him]6003-a fine human being now no more ? That was the real pity of it . Was [she]4390-dear wife to blame for that ? [She]4390-dear wife could n't state a case against [herself]4390-dear wife , and yet [she]4390-dear wife felt [she]4390-dear wife was to blame . [She]4390-dear wife had taken [him]6003-a fine human being away from those things , forced [him]6003-a fine human being to make money .... [She]4390-dear wife sat chin on hand staring into the fire , the sock forgotten on [her]4390-dear wife knee . [She]4390-dear wife could not weigh justice between [herself]4390-dear wife and [him]6003-a fine human being . If [he]6003-a fine human being was unhappy it was [her]4390-dear wife fault . [She]4390-dear wife knew if [he]6003-a fine human being was unhappy it was no excuse that [she]4390-dear wife had not known , had been misled , had a right to [her]4390-dear wife own instincts and purposes . [She]4390-dear wife had got to make [him]6003-a fine human being happy . But what was [she]4390-dear wife to do , what was there for [her]4390-dear wife to do ? ... Only [he]6003-a fine human being could work out [his]6003-a fine human being own salvation , and until [he]6003-a fine human being had light , all [she]4390-dear wife could do was to stand by [him]6003-a fine human being , help [him]6003-a fine human being , cease to irritate [him]6003-a fine human being , watch , wait . Anyhow [she]4390-dear wife could at least mend [his]6003-a fine human being socks as well as possible , so that the threads would not chafe [him]6003-a fine human being .... [She]4390-dear wife flashed to [her]4390-dear wife feet . What was that ? It seemed to [her]4390-dear wife [she]4390-dear wife had heard the sound of a shot , and a quick brief wake of echoes . [She]4390-dear wife looked across [the icy waste of [the river]4906-the river]6011-the icy waste of the river , and then up [the tangled slopes of [the mountain]6014-the mountain]6013-the tangled slopes of the mountain . [Her]4390-dear wife heart was beating very fast . It must have been up there , and no doubt [he]6003-a fine human being had killed [his]6003-a fine human being beast . Some shadow of doubt [she]4390-dear wife would not admit crossed that obvious suggestion . [This wilderness]5948-this wilderness was making [her]4390-dear wife as nervously responsive as [a creature of the wild]6016-a creature of the wild . Came a second shot ; this time there was no doubt of it . Then the desolate silence closed about [her]4390-dear wife again . [She]4390-dear wife stood for a long time staring at the shrubby slopes that rose to [the barren rock wilderness of [the purple mountain crest]6018-the purple mountain crest]6017-the barren rock wilderness of the purple mountain crest . [She]4390-dear wife sighed deeply at last , and set [herself]4390-dear wife to make up the fire and prepare for the mid - day meal . Once far away across [the river]4906-the river [she]4390-dear wife heard the howl of a wolf . Time seemed to pass very slowly that day . [She]4390-dear wife found [herself]4390-dear wife going repeatedly to the space between [the day tent]6020-the day tent and [the sleeping hut]6021-the sleeping hut from which [she]4390-dear wife could see the stunted wood that had swallowed [him]4391-he up , and after what seemed a long hour [her]4390-dear wife watch told [her]4390-dear wife it was still only half - past twelve . And the fourth or fifth time that [she]4390-dear wife went to look out [she]4390-dear wife was set atremble again by the sound of a third shot . And then at regular intervals out of that distant brown purple jumble of thickets against the snow came two more shots . "[0-i] Something has happened , " [she]4390-dear wife said , "[4391-he] something has happened , " and stood rigid . Then [she]4390-dear wife became active , seized the rifle that was always at hand when [she]4390-dear wife was alone , fired into the sky and stood listening . Prompt come an answering shot . "[4391-he] [He]4391-he wants [me]0-i , " said [Marjorie]323-marjorie . "[4391-he] Something —— Perhaps [he]4391-he has killed something too big to bring ! " [She]4390-dear wife was for starting at once , and then remembered this was not the way of [the wilderness]4183-the wilderness . [She]4390-dear wife thought and moved very rapidly . [Her]4390-dear wife mind catalogued possible requirements , rifle , hunting knife , the oilskin bag with matches , and some chunks of dry paper , the rucksack — and [he]4391-he would be hungry . [She]4390-dear wife took a saucepan and a huge chunk of cheese and biscuit . Then a brandy flask is sometimes handy — [one]675-one never knows . Though nothing was wrong , of course . Needles and stout thread , and some cord . Snowshoes . A waterproof cloak could be easily carried . [Her]4390-dear wife light hatchet for wood . [She]4390-dear wife cast about to see if there was anything else . [She]4390-dear wife had almost forgotten cartridges — and a revolver . Nothing more . [She]4390-dear wife kicked a stray brand or so into the fire , put on some more wood , damped the fire with an armful of snow to make it last longer , and set out towards the willows into which [he]4391-he had vanished . There was a rustling and snapping of branches as [she]4390-dear wife pushed [her]4390-dear wife way through the bushes , a little stir that died insensibly into quiet again ; and then [the camping place]6024-the camping place became very still .... Scarcely a sound occurred , except for the little shuddering and stirring of the fire , and the reluctant , infrequent drip from the icicles along the sunny edge of the log hut roof . About one o'clock the amber sunshine faded out altogether , a veil of clouds thickened and became greyly ominous , and a little after two the first flakes of a snowstorm fell hissing into the fire . A wind rose and drove the multiplying snowflakes in whirls and eddies before it . The icicles ceased to drip , but one or two broke and fell with a weak tinkling . A deep soughing , a shuddering groaning of trees and shrubs , came ever and again out of [the ravine]6025-the ravine , and the powdery snow blew like puffs of smoke from the branches . By four the fire was out , and the snow was piling high in the darkling twilight against [tent and hut]6026-tent and hut .... [[Trafford]394-trafford 's trail]6027-trafford 's trail led [Marjorie]323-marjorie through [the thicket of dwarf willows]6028-the thicket of dwarf willows and down to the gully of [the rivulet which [they]6030-they had called [Marjorie Trickle]221-marjorie trickle]6029-the rivulet which they had called marjorie trickle ; [it]6029-the rivulet which they had called marjorie trickle had long since become [a trough of snow - covered rotten ice]6031-a trough of snow - covered rotten ice ; [the trail]4225-the trail crossed this and , turning sharply uphill , went on until it was clear of shrubs and trees , and in the windy open of [the upper slopes]6033-the upper slopes [it]4225-the trail crossed a ridge and came over the lip of [a large desolate valley with slopes of ice and icy snow]6034-a large desolate valley with slopes of ice and icy snow . Here [she]4390-dear wife spent some time in following [his]4391-he loops back on [the homeward trail]6035-the homeward trail before [she]4390-dear wife saw what was manifestly the final trail running far away out across the snow , with the spoor of the lynx , a lightly - dotted line , to the right of [it]4225-the trail . [She]4390-dear wife followed this suggestion of [the trail]4225-the trail , put on [her]4390-dear wife snowshoes , and shuffled [her]4390-dear wife way across [this valley]6037-this valley , which opened as [she]4390-dear wife proceeded . [She]4390-dear wife hoped that over [the ridge]6038-the ridge [she]4390-dear wife would find [Trafford]394-trafford , and scanned the sky for the faintest discolouration of a fire , but there was none . That seemed odd to [her]4390-dear wife , but the wind was in [her]4390-dear wife face , and perhaps it beat the smoke down . Then as [her]4390-dear wife eyes scanned [the hummocky ridge ahead]6039-the hummocky ridge ahead , [she]4390-dear wife saw something , something very intent and still , that brought [her]4390-dear wife heart into [her]4390-dear wife mouth . It was [a big , grey wolf , standing with back haunched and head down , watching and winding something beyond there]6040-a big , grey wolf , standing with back haunched and head down , watching and winding something beyond there , out of sight . [Marjorie]323-marjorie had an instinctive fear of wild animals , and it still seemed dreadful to [her]4390-dear wife that [they]6041-they should go at large , uncaged . [She]323-marjorie suddenly wanted [Trafford]394-trafford violently , wanted [him]6042-his by [her]323-marjorie side . Also [she]323-marjorie thought of leaving [the trail]4225-the trail , going back to the bushes . [She]323-marjorie had to take [herself]323-marjorie in hand . In [the wastes]6044-the wastes [one]675-one did not fear wild beasts . [One]675-one had no fear of [them]6041-they . But why not fire a shot to let [him]6042-his know [she]323-marjorie was near ? The beast flashed round with an animal 's instantaneous change of pose , and looked at [her]323-marjorie . For a couple of seconds , perhaps , [woman]2467-woman and [brute]6048-brute regarded one another across a quarter of a mile of snowy desolation . Suppose it came towards [her]323-marjorie ! [She]323-marjorie would fire — and [she]323-marjorie would fire at it . [She]323-marjorie made a guess at the range and aimed very carefully . [She]323-marjorie saw the snow fly two yards ahead of the grisly shape , and then in an instant it had vanished over the crest . [She]323-marjorie reloaded , and stood for a moment waiting for [Trafford]394-trafford 's answer . No answer came . "[4391-he] Queer ! " [she]323-marjorie whispered , "[4391-he] queer!"—and suddenly such a horror of anticipation assailed [her]323-marjorie that [she]323-marjorie started running and floundering through the snow to escape it . Twice [she]323-marjorie called [his]6042-his name , and once [she]323-marjorie just stopped [herself]323-marjorie from firing a shot . Over [the ridge]6038-the ridge [she]323-marjorie would find [him]6042-his . Surely [she]323-marjorie would find [him]6042-his over [the ridge]6038-the ridge . [She]323-marjorie found [herself]323-marjorie among rocks , and there was a beaten and trampled place where [Trafford]394-trafford must have waited and crouched . Then on and down [a slope of tumbled boulders]6051-a slope of tumbled boulders . There came a patch where [he]6042-his had either thrown [himself]6042-his down or fallen . It seemed to [her]323-marjorie [he]6042-his must have been running .... Suddenly , a hundred feet or so away , [she]323-marjorie saw a patch of violently disturbed snow — snow stained a dreadful colour , a snow of scarlet crystals ! Three strides and [Trafford]394-trafford was in sight . [She]323-marjorie had a swift conviction [he]6042-his was dead . [He]6042-his was lying in a crumpled attitude on a patch of snow between convergent rocks , and the lynx , a mass of blood smeared silvery fur , was in some way mixed up with [him]6042-his . [She]323-marjorie saw as [she]323-marjorie came nearer that the snow was disturbed round about [them]6052-them , and discoloured copiously , yellow widely , and in places bright red , with congealed and frozen blood . [She]323-marjorie felt no fear now , and no emotion ; all [her]323-marjorie mind was engaged with the clear , bleak perception of the fact before [her]323-marjorie . [She]323-marjorie did not care to call to [him]6042-his again . [His]6042-his head was hidden by the lynx 's body , it was as if [he]6042-his was burrowing underneath the creature ; [his]6042-his legs were twisted about each other in a queer , unnatural attitude . Then , as [she]323-marjorie dropped off a boulder , and came nearer , [Trafford]394-trafford moved . A hand came out and gripped the rifle beside [him]6042-his ; [he]6042-his suddenly lifted a dreadful face , horribly scarred and torn , and crimson with frozen blood ; [he]6042-his pushed the grey beast aside , rose on an elbow , wiped [his]6042-his sleeve across [his]6042-his eyes , stared at [her]323-marjorie , grunted , and flopped forward . [He]6042-his had fainted . [She]323-marjorie was now as clear - minded and as self - possessed as [a woman in [a shop]1786-a shop]6053-a woman in a shop . In another moment [she]323-marjorie was kneeling by [his]6042-his side . [She]323-marjorie saw , by the position of [his]6042-his knife and the huge rip in the beast 's body , that [he]6042-his had stabbed the lynx to death as it clawed [his]6042-his head ; [he]6042-his must have shot and wounded it and then fallen upon it . [His]6042-his knitted cap was torn to ribbons , and hung upon [his]6042-his neck . Also [his]6042-his leg was manifestly injured ; how , [she]323-marjorie could not tell . It was chiefly evident [he]6042-his must freeze if [he]6042-his lay here . It seemed to [her]323-marjorie that perhaps [he]6042-his had pulled [the dead brute]6055-the dead brute over [him]6042-his to protect [his]6042-his torn skin from the extremity of cold . The lynx was already rigid , its clumsy paws asprawl — the torn skin and clot upon [Trafford]394-trafford 's face was stiff as [she]323-marjorie put [her]323-marjorie hands about [his]6042-his head to raise [him]6042-his . [She]323-marjorie turned [him]6042-his over on [his]6042-his back — how heavy [he]6042-his seemed!—and forced brandy between [his]6042-his teeth . [She]323-marjorie glanced at [his]6042-his leg , which was surely broken , and back at [his]6042-his face . Then [she]323-marjorie gave [him]6042-his more brandy and [his]6042-his eyelids flickered . [He]6042-his moved [his]6042-his hand weakly . "[4391-he] The blood , " [he]6042-his said , "[4391-he] kept getting in [my]0-i eyes . " [She]323-marjorie gave [him]6042-his brandy once again , wiped [his]6042-his face and glanced at [his]6042-his leg . Something ought to be done to that [she]323-marjorie thought . But things must be done in order . [She]323-marjorie stared up at the darkling sky with its grey promise of snow , and down [the slopes of [the mountain]6014-the mountain]6056-the slopes of the mountain . [They]6058-they were too high for wood among [these rocks]6059-these rocks , but three or four hundred yards below there were a number of dwarfed fir trees . [She]323-marjorie had brought an axe , so that a fire was possible . Should [she]323-marjorie go back to [camp]6060-camp and get [the tent]4234-the tent ? [A hummock to the westward]6063-a hummock to the westward offered shelter from the weakly bitter wind , the icy draught , that was soughing down [the valley]4295-the valley .
